Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Atomistic Simulations of the Nanotribology of Carbon-based Materials: Establishing Links between Structure, Chemistry, and Performance

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objectives of this work are to complete development of a fluctuating-charge molecular dynamics code and potential energy function that are capable of reliably capturing bond breaking and forming events that occur between carbon-based materials and oxygen-containing environmental species, such as water. The phrase "carbon-based materials" encompasses a broad range of materials, including the building blocks of biology, allotropes of carbon, and carbon-based films. Because carbon-based solid lubricants have desirable properties, such as high hardness and ultralow friction and wear, they are being used or considered for a wide range of applications that include space systems, micro-electromechanical systems, orthopedic implants, computer hard disks, and as scaffolds on which to build DNA-based microsensors. Perhaps the most significant factor that has prevented even wider spread use of carbon-based materials as solid lubricants is the sensitivity of their friction to the environment. This project will also validate a potential energy function based on a similar formalism that can model dynamics in Si-, C- and H- containing systems. Knowledge gained from these development projects can be used to create a potential capable of modeing chemical reactions in Si-, O- and H- containing systems with charge. These tools can then be used to examine the nanotribology and mechanical properties of carbon-based material in the presence of water, the properties of Si-doped DLC, and epitaxial graphene on Si-C.

If successful, this research effort will provide several new tools that can be used to examine dynamics at the atomic scale. In addition, a fundamental understanding of the way in which environmental species, such as water, impact carbon-based solid lubricant performance will be developed. This knowledge will allow for the rational design of carbon-based solid lubricants with the desired tribological and mechanical properties and increase the viability of applications where carbon-based solid lubricant films can be used. Also as part of this project, a broad range of middle and high school students will be introduced to nanotribology via the integration of a nanotribology module into the existing USNA STEM program and into the DAPCEP program at OU. Nanotribology modules will also be developed for graduate-level tribology classes at OU.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diamondlike carbon (DLC), with and without dopants, and ultrananocrystalline diamond (UNCD) have desirable properties such as high hardness and ultralow friction and wear. Thus, they are being used or considered for a wide range of applications including space systems, microelectromechanical systems, orthopedic implants, computer hard disks, and as scaffolds on which to build DNA-based microsensors. One overarching goal of this work was the development of potential energy functions capable of modeling chemical reactions in molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of these technologically relevant materials. To this end, we incorporated the electronegative element oxygen into the AIREBO potential for carbon and hydrogen by merging charge equilibration with bond-order potentials in a way that does not require molecules to be the charge neutral entities. The so-called qAIREBO potential (Fig. 1), and the associated MD code, makes use of a bond-centered approach, which is a variation of the split-charge equilibration method, that links the maximum shared charge to the bond order. This implementation of the reactive potential is able to model chemical reactions where partial charges change in gas- and condensed-phase systems containing oxygen, carbon, and hydrogen. In the earlier stages of this project, several parameters were finalized and the potential published. In the latter part of the project, simulations examining the effects of submonolayer amounts of interfacial water on the adhesion, compression, and friction of UNCD and DLC surfaces was examined.

MD simulations examining the effect of compression water confined between two UNCD surfaces were carried out with coverages of 0.04 molecules/Å2 (64 H2O molecules) and 0.08 molecules/Å2 (128 H2O molecules). In both cases, the force on the upper surface, a measure of the elastic modulus, showed two distinct regions corresponding to the compression and spreading of the water and the compression of the UNCD surfaces. At large surface separations, interfacial water molecules form hydrogen-bonded droplets, or aggregates. For the higher coverage, compression led to the layering and ‘squeezing out’ of successive layers of water. When small amounts of water were present, it was compressed into a single layer without passing through a conformation with two or more water layers. In both cases examined, once a single layer of water is present, it arranges itself on the underlying UNCD surface so that hydrogen-bonding is maximized with most of the waters in the crystalline regions of the UNCD (Fig. 2). This potential was also used to examine the adhesion between axisymmetric tips and substrates of carbon-based materials (Fig. 3).

To model silicon, silicon carbide, and silicon-doped DLCs, the development of the 2B-SiCH potential was finalized and was published. This potential is an extension of the reactive empirical bond-order (REBO) potential for hydrocarbons and silicon with improvements in elastic constants, surface energies of carbon and silicon containing surfaces, and molecular energies for organosilane molecules (Fig. 4). This potential has been used to examine the atomistic explanation for the mechanical response and friction of crystalline silicon and silicon carbide tips as well as amorphous silicon carbide (a-SiC) tips. Interestingly, and in contrast with experiment, at high loads the softest tip had the lowest friction when in contact with hydrogen-terminated diamond surfaces. Presumably the small size of the contact examined in the simulations compared to the experiment reduces the possibility of tip cleavage along a defect, which would reduce friction.
